text: Retirement Planning in Singapore: Trends, Challenges, and Solutions

details: Rapidly ageing populations in Asia pose challenges for governments, employers, households, and financial institutions.
Many retirement income systems in Asia are not prepared for rapid population ageing.
Increasingly, individuals are responsible for their retirement income security.
Online surveys and focus group discussions with over a thousand Singaporeans and Permanent Residents aged 18-60.
76% of respondents stated retirement as their main long-term financial goal.
Only 25% have implemented a financial plan for retirement; 50% have no plan at all.
24% cite confusion on financial products; 23% believe they lack funds to start.
Respondents expect S$3,500 per month for 15-20 years.
Calculations suggest S$900,000 needed for retirement at age 65.
Respondents contribute to savings accounts, fixed deposits, ETFs, unit trusts, annuities, and endowment plans.
Begin planning and saving as early as possible.
Create a clear financial plan and start saving, even small amounts.
Define retirement goals, take stock of assets, evaluate health, create a budget, and cut unnecessary expenses.
Use retirement tools and seek advice from specialists.
Save regularly, protect against financial risks with insurance, and invest to grow retirement funds.
The rising number of elderly people will impact Singaporeâ€™s economy.
Many expect to work past the official retirement age to complement their incomes.
Retirement savings may only last for 12 out of 18 expected years in retirement.
Emphasis on self-reliance and early planning for future retirees.
Singaporeans have high aspirations for their retirement but are often unprepared.
Early planning, trust, discipline, and communication are key to a stress-free retirement.
